Merit-based promotions will only get you so far, expect to play corporate politics if you want to move further up from this corner of the business.
Training for this position comes in the form of asking more senior peers for assistance and guidance.

- Placement requirements for Full-Time Roles are INCONSISTENT. Lots of inconsistent guidelines and rules. Some people will be placement eligible BELOW 75% because their 'sales managers fought for them since they are GREAT reps'. Others, who have worked hard to earn over 75%, may not be placement eligible if an Order Number for a sale has not yet been processed - which is ultimately the SYSTEM'S error, not the sales rep's fault. 
- ORDER NUMBERS can take 1-2 MONTHS TO SHOW UP. This is a flawed system because it not only messes with your Month-to-Date sales number, but it also affects your Year-to-Date Attainment which is CRITICAL for placement eligibility. You may sell something in October that you will not get credit for until December. Absolutely flawed system in place that is setting you up for FAILURE.
- Very unethical training methods in place. Management will get on a call with you and 'coach' you, to the point where it is borderline VERBAL HARASSMENT. 
- Technical consultants, who are supposed to be there to answer any technical questions you may have, are very snappy and short with you. I think they can be smart and helpful otherwise, but there are way too many sales reps that are asking them questions. This leaves them impatient and UNWILLING to help you. They will turn you away and tell you to figure it out on your own. 
- Let's say you make over 75% YTD Attainment and you get placed in a Full-Time role. Guess what? You have to sign a contract that binds you to stay in the position for 18 MONTHS. If you leave anytime before, you will be asked to pay back $13,000.
- When you're chosen to pick a location and role for placement, you are given FIVE minutes to choose in a Webex call. If you are 1 minute late to the call, you are given FOUR minutes. You are not given preferable locations to choose from. You can only lock in a certain region in the U.S., and from there, you pick a state and role based on THEIR availability. 
- During month 3, you will begin receiving inbound calls from Small Business customers. You're practically working a call center job where you are fixing billing issues, customer service issues, and trying to up-sell Small Business owners that are simply calling in to renew their existing service. Management will listen to these calls and send you lengthy e-mails on what you did wrong, word by word.
- Management will lie to you to keep you happy. They will lie that you are PROMISED placement, that they are ACTIVELY working on an issue for you, that you are SAFE to stay in the program, that SOMEONE ELSE is responsible for handling this problem but when you go to that SOMEONE ELSE, they don't have the authority to make any changes... Absolutely inefficient and irresponsible behavior as management of a leading telecommunications business.
- Micromanagement all around. In a real corporate job, you don't need TWO check-ins a day. They treat you like babies because you are new grads and helicopter over you.
- If you are given another job offer, please take the latter. AT&T sounds like a great opportunity because of its name and reputable sales program, but you will ultimately waste your time if you end up getting CUT. The moment you begin this role, you will spend your days worrying about your job security. A lot of cold-calling is LUCK. Someone can make 100+ cold calls/emails a day with NO RESULTS. It will mess with your mental well-being.
